column1: The North Macedonia national football team (Macedonian: Фудбалска репрезентација нa Северна Македонија
column2: romanized: Fudbalska reprezentacija na Severna Makedonija) represents North Macedonia in international football
column3: and is controlled by the Football Federation of North Macedonia. The national team plays its home matches at the Toshe Proeski Arena in Skopje.

column2: since independence
column3: has been regarded as the weakest and least successful post-Yugoslav national teams
column4: with the team often performing below expectation. North Macedonia has achieved some impressive performances
column5: however
column6: such as two draws against England away
column7: two draws to the Netherlands both away and home
column8: a draw to Slovakia at home
column10: and a win against Serbia at home.

column2: as part of the 100-year anniversary of football on its current territory
column3: the national team played a friendly match against Spain. Star player Goran Pandev scored two goals in the first half to give Macedonia a 2–0 lead before Spain scored three goals in the second half to record the 3–2 victory in front of a record crowd of 30
column4: 000 at the renovated Philip II Arena.

column1: North Macedonia national football team represents North Macedonia in international football
column2: and its controlled by the Football Federation of North Macedonia. In the period between 1945 and 1991
column3: SR Macedonia was ineligible to play as team for official matches. The team had mostly played exhibition matches against teams from other republics of SFRJ and was represented by Macedonian players under the traditional red
column4: yellow and white colors. The first football clubs were formed in Ottoman times at the beginning of the 20th century.

column2: Macedonia became a single member of FIFA
column3: and UEFA after the independence and split of the Yugoslavia. The national team began its football journey with a 4–1 victory against Slovenia in a friendly on 13 October 1993 under coach Andon Dončevski.They went on to win their next two friendlies against Slovenia and Estonia . The inaugural Macedonian side featured Darko Pančev
column4: who played for Inter Milan in Italy.

column1: The Euro 96 Qualifiers was the first major qualifying tournament that Macedonia participated in as an independent nation and they were grouped with Spain
column2: Denmark
column3: Belgium
column4: Cyprus and Armenia. In their opening game
column5: which was also their first ever official match
column6: Macedonia was drawn against the reigning European Champions Denmark.

column1: The game was played in Skopje on 7 September 1994 and it finished 1–1 with Macedonia leading for most of the game after scoring in the fourth minute. In this qualifying stage
column2: Macedonia suffered one of its worst defeats when they lost 0–5 to Belgium at home on 7 June 1995. They failed to qualify for Euro 96
column3: finishing fourth in the group with seven points.

column2: Kanatlarovski and Jovanovski's era (1996–2001) ===

column1: Macedonia's first qualifying attempt for the World Cup saw them grouped with Romania

column3: Lithuania
column4: Iceland
column5: and Liechtenstein.

column1: The tournament began on 24 April 1996 with a 3–0 win at home against Liechtenstein. On 9 November 1996
column2: Macedonia recorded their biggest win ever
column3: an 11–1 thrashing of Liechtenstein. Half of the goals Macedonia scored in the entire campaign were scored in this match alone. Macedonia failed again to qualify for the 1998 World Cup in France
column4: finishing fourth in the group on 13 points.

column1: Macedonia's journey to qualify for the Euro 2000 tournament in the Netherlands and Belgium saw them grouped with FR Yugoslavia
column2: Ireland
column3: Croatia
column4: and Malta. They once again opened their qualifying campaign with a win after beating Malta 4–0 at home on 6 September 1998. Their most notable result in the campaign was a 1–1 draw against Croatia in June 1999
column5: with an equaliser of Gjorgji Hristov 10 minutes before the end of the game. They were helped Yugoslavia to qualify directly and eliminate Croatia
column6: because were drawn 1–1 against Republic of Ireland with a last minute equaliser of Goran Stavrevski. However
column8: finishing fourth in the group with eight points.

column1: Macedonia's 2002 World Cup qualifying campaign saw them grouped with Sweden
column2: Turkey
column3: Slovakia
column4: Moldova
column5: and Azerbaijan. They were unsuccessful in their opening match
column6: going down to Slovakia 2–0 in Slovakia on 3 September 2000. The Macedonians once again failed to qualify for the 2002 World Cup
column7: which was held in Japan and South Korea
column8: as they finished fourth in the group with seven points.

column1: The Euro 2004 Qualifiers saw Macedonia grouped alongside England
column2: Turkey
column3: Slovakia
column4: and Liechtenstein. Despite Macedonia failing to win its first four games of the campaign
column5: they managed to record one of its most memorable results of its short history.

column2: Macedonia played former world champions England in Southampton
column3: which was England's first home game in Southampton in almost 100 years. Macedonia grabbed the lead early in the first half after Artim Šakiri scored directly from a corner kick
column4: leaving English goalkeeper David Seaman stunned. England soon levelled the game
column5: but not before Macedonia managed to take the lead once again.

column2: the game ended 2–2 after England managed to score a second equaliser in the second half. Macedonia lost to England 2–1 at home in the return leg
column3: which took place in September 2003. Macedonia's only win of the campaign came on 7 June 2003
column4: when they beat Liechtenstein 3–1 at home. Macedonia did not qualify for the Euro 2004 tournament
column5: which was held in Portugal
column6: finishing fourth in the group with six points.

column1: Macedonia was drawn in Group 1 and was grouped with the Netherlands
column2: Czech Republic
column3: Romania
column4: Finland
column5: Armenia
column6: and Andorra. They managed to open their campaign with a comfortable 3–0 win at home against Armenia on 18 August 2004. Macedonia did not win another home game for more than three years.

column2: Macedonia managed to hold the Netherlands to a surprise 2–2 draw in Skopje in front of a crowd of 17
column3: 000 at the Skopje City Stadium
column4: but in their next game
column5: just four days later
column6: they suffered one of its most embarrassing defeats
column8: one of the world's weakest teams. Also in this tournament
column9: Macedonia set a new team record for most goals conceded in a game when they lost 6–1 away to Czech Republic on 8 June 2005.

column1: Macedonia went on to concede a further eight goals in the next two qualifying games
column2: both against Finland. On 23 August 2005
column3: coach Slobodan Santrač resigned as coach of Macedonia after just five months on the job due to personal problems
column4: with former player Boban Babunski temporarily taking over as coach. The resignation came just days after they were beaten 3–0 by Finland in Skopje. Despite their poor performance during the 2006 World Cup qualifying campaign
column5: Macedonia managed to end the campaign on a high with a 0–0 draw against the Netherlands in Amsterdam.This result meant that Macedonia
column6: with the two draws against the Netherlands
column7: was the only team in the group not to have been defeated by the Netherlands. The Netherlands won 10 of their 12 games in the 2006 World Cup campaign. Macedonia failed to qualify for the 2006 World Cup in Germany
column8: finishing fifth in the group with nine points.

column1: Following the completion of the 2006 World Cup qualifying tournament
column2: in November 2005
column3: Macedonia took part in a friendly tournament in Iran consisting of four teams
column4: each team from a different continent. The teams were Macedonia
column5: Iran
column6: Paraguay
column7: and Togo. In their opening match
column8: they won 2–1 against host nation Iran
column9: booking a spot in the final against Paraguay. They lost the final against Paraguay 0–1. Macedonia was the only nation in this friendly tournament not to have qualified for the 2006 World Cup.

column1: === Srečko Katanec's era and best FIFA ranking (2006–10) ===

column2: Macedonia was placed in Group E for the Euro 2008 qualifiers alongside England
column3: Croatia
column4: Russia
column5: Israel
column6: Estonia
column8: former Slovenian national team coach Srečko Katanec was appointed as the head coach and was given a two-year contract.

column1: In the lead-up to the beginning of the qualifiers for Euro 2008
column2: Macedonia managed two results against sides in friendly matches. They beat Ecuador 2–1 in Madrid
column3: their first ever win against a South American nation
column4: and a week later
column5: followed that up with a 1–0 win against Turkey.

column1: Macedonia opened their UEFA Euro 2008 qualifying campaign with a 0–1 win away to Estonia on 16 August 2006. Goce Sedloski scored for Macedonia in the 73rd minute
column2: which meant that Macedonia was the first team to score a goal in the Euro 2008 qualifying campaign. Macedonia hosted England on 6 September 2006 in their second game of the qualifiers. England went on to win 0–1 after Peter Crouch scored for the away side in the 46th minute. This was the first time that Macedonia failed to score against England.A month later
column3: on 7 October 2006
column4: the two teams met once again in Manchester
column5: where England was held to a 0–0 draw in front of 72
column6: 062 people. On 17 October 2007
column7: Macedonia recorded their first win on home soil since August 2004 when they easily defeated Andorra 3–0 in Skopje in an emotional game as it was the day after the death of pop icon Toše Proeski.Macedonia then recorded one of their most impressive wins to date when they picked up a 2–0 victory over eventual group winners Croatia on 17 November 2007
column8: causing the biggest upset of Group A; it was also a first win for Macedonia over a side that was ranked in the top ten of the FIFA World Rankings. Despite some surprising results
column9: Macedonia once again failed to qualify for the Euro 2008 Finals after finishing fifth in the group with 14 points.

column1: === Country's name change and recent years (2018–present) ===
==== 2018–19 UEFA Nations League & Euro 2020 qualifiers: rise ====
In the first edition of the UEFA Nations League
column2: Macedonia played in League D
column3: the fourth and lowest division of that competition. Macedonia were drawn in Group 4 with Armenia
column4: Liechtenstein and Gibraltar. The national team won the group with five wins and one loss
column5: and were promoted to the League C for the next edition of the Nations League. Macedonia were assured of a UEFA Euro 2020 qualifying play-offs place.

column1: Macedonia was renamed North Macedonia after the Prespa agreement came into force on 12 February 2019. For the UEFA Euro 2020 qualifying North Macedonia were placed in Group G
column2: along with Austria
column3: Israel
column4: Latvia
column5: Poland and Slovenia. North Macedonia managed two first impressive results
column6: drawing Slovenia 1–1 away and before that
column8: to put their hope high to qualify for the first ever UEFA Euro. However
column9: North Macedonia would soon face setbacks when they faced off stronger sides
column10: with the team fell 0–1 to Poland and 1–4 to Austria
column11: both games were played in Skopje. The situation got some improvement
column12: with the team achieved a successful 1–1 away draw to Israel
column14: a 2–1 win over Slovenia at home soil that gave North Macedonia some chances to reach top two
column16: indirectly helped to relieve pressure for Poland. Yet
column17: it was Poland that killed off North Macedonia's hope to achieve a top two finish
column18: when North Macedonia lost 0–2 away to Poland. With the hope dented
column19: North Macedonia lost 1–2 away to Austria and had to finish in third place
column20: the highest position achieved in North Macedonian football history.However
column21: due to having successfully taken the first place in the UEFA Nations League earlier
column22: North Macedonia was able to reach the country's first ever competitive playoff in the history
column23: and was scheduled against Kosovo. Eventually
column24: in the UEFA Euro 2020 qualifying play-offs first game
column25: North Macedonia overcame Kosovo 2–1 at home
column26: thus increased the chance to make a historic Euro debut for North Macedonia when they will face Georgia in the final of League D's play-offs.

column1: After winning the League D group in the first edition of the UEFA Nations League

The North Macedonia national football team has yet to qualify for a World Cup finals tournament. In their attempt at qualifying for the 2010 World Cup
column2: they finished fourth in Group 9 with seven points. Surprisingly
column3: due to the closeness of the group throughout the campaign (only five teams in the group)
column4: Macedonia remained in contention to qualify until the final group game
column5: which Macedonia lost 2–1 away to Norway
column6: although Norway would be the only runner up to not make the playoffs that year.
